awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The interplay between fluctuating selection on symbionts and life cycle evolution in sap-sucking insects
awd_abstract_narration:
Insects that feed on the sap of their host plants, including many crop and forest pests, have within them beneficial bacteria that provide the insects with essential nutrients that are missing from their diet. This research quantifies how the properties of those bacteria have been affected by evolutionary changes in insect diets; it further explores the role that the bacteria have played in how the insects use new host plants and in the insect's life cycle. This knowledge is important because it highlights bacteria as hidden players in major aspects of insect ecology and evolution. Information from this project may also assist in the control of several forest pest insects. This project will provide training for graduate students, undergraduates, and high-school students, including individuals from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences, and will promote public events to enhance scientific literacy and appreciation for research.

This project studies Adelgidae insects that feed on conifer trees, and their dual symbionts. It tests the hypothesis that fluctuating demands for nutrient provisioning in insects has led to symbiont replacements, which in turn have precipitated new host-plant acquisitions and life-cycle complexity. Specific objectives include (1) establishing a family-wide pattern of the unusual role allocations between dual symbionts; (2) quantifying the contributions of symbionts and insect hosts to nutrient provisioning as a measure of adjustment to nutrient availability; (3) quantifying rates of evolution in symbiont genomes under different insect feeding modes. These objectives will be accomplished through DNA and RNA sequencing of symbiont genomes and expressed insect genes that support symbiont functions.

por.por_cntn:
All complex organisms, including humans, depend on close associations with microbes for their health and well-being. Many of these associations involve microbes that provide nutrition for their host. In most insects, such partnerships, or symbioses, have been stable for many millions of years, and have allowed the insects to exploit nutrient-poor diets. Such symbioses have therefore been foundational in the great diversifications of several insect groups. This project investigated the specialized bacterial communities living within sap-sucking insects, the Adelgidae, which feed on conifer trees. Two such insects introduced to North America are devastating forest pests. This insect group is unusual in that their bacterial partnerships appear to be unstable and may have experienced turnover during the insects? speciation. The central question this work addressed was: have fluctuations in the nutrient content of the insects? diet driven loss and gain of bacterial symbionts, which in turn drove the evolution of life cycles and the ability to feed on new host tree species?

In previous work we had identified the two bacterial partners of an adelgid species, the devastating hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae), responsible for massive die-off of hemlock trees in the eastern U.S. In this project we used a combination of gene sequencing, genomics, transcriptomics, and microscopy to explore the diversity of symbionts in the adelgid family, their functions, and their role in adelgid evolution. In addition, we sequenced the genome of one adelgid species, Adelges cooleyi (Cooley spruce gall adelgid). We found that all adelgids have two symbiont partners and together they synthesize essential nutrients that are missing from tree sap. The genome of one symbiont in the hemlock woolly adelgid Pseudomonas species, contained many genes of unknown function. These could be investigated in the future to determine whether they play a role in the virulence of the insect on hemlocks. Work on other adelgids revealed a diverse set of bacteria and a dynamic pattern of symbiont gains and losses over a short evolutionary time compared to other sap-sucking insects. This turnover resulted in each adelgid species possessing different pairs of an older symbiont and a younger symbiont. We found that genomes of older symbiont partners tended to be more degraded than younger symbionts and contributed fewer essential nutrients. We proposed the hypothesis that adelgid life cycles and host-plant associations evolved due to periodic relaxed demands on symbiont function, with the degradation of older symbionts and repeated acquisition of new symbionts creating opportunities for colonization of new conifer hosts. Our findings bring new insights into the process of complex life cycle evolution.

The complex life cycles of adelgids entail multiple clonal generations that alternate between two conifers, spruce and either pine, hemlock, Douglas-fir, true fir, or larch. On spruce, the insects live and feed in galls, a tumor-like plant growth. On the other conifer species, the insects feed on needles. Central to our hypothesis was the assumption that nutrition is much enhanced in galls, which are nutrient sinks, but depleted on needles. This would set up fluctuations in nutrient demand from symbionts over the course of the life cycle, leading to loss of function. We found that indeed, adelgid generations in galls were much larger than those on needles. Methods for dissecting insect organs containing symbionts were established and used to determine that gall-feeders had fewer host cells containing symbionts than generations on needles, and needle-feeding generations had much higher densities of symbionts per body mass. This supports our assumption that gall-feeding generations obtain higher nutrition in galls and therefore require less support from symbionts. Overall, our results support the idea that fluctuating demand for nutrient provisioning in Adelgidae has led to symbiont replacements, precipitating new hostplant acquisitions and life-cycle complexity. Our in-progress work on transcriptomics of symbionts and the organs that house them will uncover patterns of gene expression that further test the level of nutrient provisioning by symbionts for insects feeding on galls vs needles. Our sequence of the A. cooleyi genome supports this work by integrating key insect genes that support symbiont functions.

This project provided science education opportunities for students and the public. Several graduate and undergraduate students were directly supported by the project and were trained in molecular genetic laboratory methods, genomics, bioinformatics, and evolution of symbioses. In every year of the project, one-to-three Navajo students from our Blanding statewide campus spent time in the laboratory learning about symbioses in insects and performing research on this topic. Posters they prepared on their projects were displayed to the public, including on the Navajo reservation. Newly generated gene, whole-genome, and whole-transcriptome sequences have been or will be made available to the public in online-accessible databases. Results were presented in peer-reviewed scientific publications (including open access) and conference presentations, and several more publications are expected from the results.
